report_title: Business Analytics & Enterprise Software Publishing in the US
executive_summary: The business software industry has firmly established itself as the linchpin of the modern enterprise ecosystem, reacting agilely to the ever-evolving demands of digital economic transformation. Propelled by advancements in automation and analytics and marked by a significant CAGR of 9.8% from 2018 to 2023, the bevy of enterprise software solutions has enhanced operational efficiency and fueled strategic growth across internal and external domains. Heavy investment in technologies like SaaS and no-code customization, made possible by 2023's $174.2 billion in revenue, have streamlined software deployment and update procedures - factors that notably benefit providers and end-users within a competitive landscape.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Business software use upholds the modern digital economy
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Positive trends toward automation, large capital investments and greater acceptance of technology in the workplace have stimulated high private investment in computers and software, and easy-to-implement software in particular.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Big data creates substantial opportunities and even larger privacy concerns
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Big data, which consists of data mining and predictive analytics, is one of the many buzzwords driving research and development in software. Software companies are particularly interested in developing predictive analytics to be content-neutral so the software can analyze any data set without significant modification.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Wealthy players make strategic acquisitions to expand cross-selling strategies
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: In the software development industry, many start-ups have emerged to cater to specific markets. However, established software companies continue to expand by acquiring promising smaller developers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Subscription software's service-based business model completes its takeover of the software sales model
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: In recent years, major companies have become adept in providing mobile and cloud-based software offerings, hosted either on their own servers or those of a third party like AWS, Google Cloud or Azure

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Exhaustion of massive software clients will contribute to diminished growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Small- and mid-sized businesses across various industries are expected to adopt enterprise and analytics software across all sectors. These retailers can connect their in-store systems to their database, recording detailed information about transactions, mouse positions on a webpage, items bought together, worker productivity, physical locations in a store and so much more. The use of online payment processing software across the economy will encourage the trend of companies' recording consumer trends to be later analyzed. As the benefits of enterprise and analytics software spread across several industries, demand will likely continue to strengthen, but revenue will slow as the market for big clients saturates.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Significant consequences arise from unchecked trust in business software
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Many software users have the perception that software is infallible; while this is technically true because the software will only do exactly what users tell it, human trust throughout the software use cycle has grown exponentially. Many instances of business analytics software, particularly those using the most advanced machine learning protocols, have shown bias against women, minorities and the disabled when hiring, filing insurance claims, targeting advertising and even assessing criminal risk. While major companies have received massive lawsuits for using unverified algorithms for business purposes, all business analytics companies should take steps to ensure their software is in alignment with their corporate values.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Major developers will likely refocus on analytics
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As major client implementation slows, dominant enterprise software vendors will likely continue their aggressive acquisition strategy. As companies compete to satisfy corporate consumers, the acquisition of emerging software developers and their groundbreaking technologies is expected to remain central to operations. While spooling up an internal team to solve a client problem can result in a better outcome, buying smaller companies has the added benefit of preventing a competitor from doing the same. Acquisition and injecting cash into a struggling business with promising technology can still be a significant discount. The number of industry enterprises is anticipated to edge upward, buoyed by low barriers to entry. Companies with breakthrough technologies related to data mining and predictive analytics will likely be prime targets for acquisition during the outlook period.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: End-user driven software moves toward being a standard in the business market
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Personalization in the United States business software sector is poised to reach new heights as manufacturers adapt one-size-fits-all packages to meet specific end-user preferences and operational requirements. The increasing mesh of no-code development illustrates a future where IT experts and individual employees will drive further software management post-sale, enriching their operating experience and efficiency without burdening seller resources. Still, this shift may expand the closeness between manufacturers and their clients, ensuring an ongoing engagement beyond the point of sale as clients seek documentation, customer support, and add-in features. Companies failing to catch up with this trend in the U.S. business software realm could face market share erosion due to unsatisfied client entrepreneurialism and personalization productivity.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Artificial intelligence will upend business analytics internally and externally
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Machine learning, the process of giving a computer examples of solved problems and letting it try progressively improving solutions, has been a staple in business intelligence for many years. Recent publicization of large language models, which use human speech patterns trained across millions of webpages to mimic semi-novel conversations, have empowered business owners to ask human-oriented questions of their data. Many business analysts are concerned this technology will make their services obsolete, but some others are training to optimize language models for this new environment. Overall impact on business software is expected to be moderate: many low-level analysis jobs will likely be replaced, but the fundamental value of business analytics is partially in handling novel situations; AIs are currently not excellent at these new challenges. Business analytics companies should start planning now for how they will provide value when clients are able to deploy AI systems for orders of magnitude less money than buying thousands of software license seats.

industry_definition: Companies in this industry develop and distribute business analytics, customer relationship management, business intelligence and other enterprise-oriented software. Operators may also provide consulting and technical support related to this software. This industry does not include publishers of productivity or database software or manufacturers of computer hardware.

negative_impact_factors: low - steady barriers to entry level

opportunities: Private investment in computers and software

key_trends: Enterprise software is reaching saturation in major clients. Instead, developers are switching to focus on mid-size and small business clients, as they experience far higher churn.

Businesses have wrapped around software, and its use is non-negotiable in many circumstances. This dependence has enabled developers to charge high monthly fees and profit enormously simply because clients are making business income.

As a business-to-business industry, enterprise software development experiences little regulation outside of antitrust. Even COVID-19 failed to hit the industry hard, as many developers simply worked from home.

Volatility affects the numerous software developer nonemployers far more than established enterprises. Venture capital drying up or a key client going under can sink a fledgling enterprise software hopeful.
Business software products permeate the entire business lifecycle. Clients implement software for client management, shipping, analytics and almost everything else.
Financial companies are the leading users of business software. However, businesses across the economic spectrum leverage all kinds of software creatively to save money.
Business software development companies locate near business centers. However, the rise of remote work is enabling developers to move anywhere and lower their work costs.
Companies near high-education centers can lower their hiring costs dramatically. College-work programs are becoming more common as the price of software education degrees has increased.

market_segmentation.segment_description: The communications, media and service companies segment encompasses various businesses engaged in connecting society and providing services.
The manufacturing, pharmaceuticals and life science companies segment, which focuses on physical goods creation, has significant growth potential with the reopening of the economy after the pandemic.
The largest market segment is banking, securities and insurance companies, which use software to make financially impactful decisions, generating almost half of revenue.

More significant business segments in this category include retailers, healthcare providers and utility companies. Larger healthcare providers have been replacing older technologies with ERP systems; however, smaller providers still provide an untapped market due to their limited funds.

Government organizations serving the public interest have similar needs to businesses and benefit from using software, such as ERP. Government organizations can also use data analytics software to analyze trends at massive scales. Government demand is one of the most stable software segments in this industry, especially at the federal level.
Other businesses use an absurd variety of specialized, custom software.

products_and_services.product_description: Performance management software and other products include custom-developed software used within businesses and straightforward applications, such as time-tracking software.

Customer relationship management (CRM) software is designed to coordinate the functions of an organization's sales, technical and customer support teams by using a contact management system to track and record each stage in the sales process; examples include Salesforce, Microsoft Dynamics CRM and Oracle's PeopleSoft.

Enterprise resource planning (ERP) software is designed to automate back-office functions that do not directly interact with customers, including payroll, quality control, accounts receivable, order processing and work flow management.
Business intelligence (BI) software retrieves and analyzes data, turning it into useful information and making more accurate strategic decisions.
Supply chain management (SCM) software is designed to coordinate the back-office functions of inventory management and supply purchasing, most commonly used in manufacturing.

business_locations.location_description: The Northeast Corridor, stretching from NYC to DC, offers business software companies the largest nexus of commercial activity, including unrivaled access to key financial markets and Fortune 500 clients seeking bespoke software solutions.

Silicon Valley, a veritable magnet for software development companies, thrives on its unparalleled innovation ecosystem; firms are drawn to the density of tech know-how and venture capital dollars. Proximity to academic institutions with strong software development programs affords software firms a continuous influx of top-tier graduates, imbuing the local talent pool with fresh perspectives and cutting-edge skills.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Business enterprise software vendors are increasingly under the antitrust microscope, as regulators probe into market consolidation and potential stifling of competition.
With data now the lifeblood of business software, the growing patchwork of international data protection laws (e.g., GDPR, CCPA) presents operational complexity for companies.
In 2019, the EU adopted the Directive on Copyright in the Digital Single Market, aimed at modernizing copyright law in the digital age.

barriers_points.barrier_title: Revenue volatility and technology change are high barriers
barriers_points.barrier_description: Revenue Volatility Level: high. Technology Change Level: high.

barriers_points.barrier_title: Industry assistance and competition levels are increasing barriers
barriers_points.barrier_description: Industry Assistance Level: low - steady. Competition Level: high - increasing.

basis_points.basis_title: Large software companies benefit from transforming global business
basis_points.basis_description: Large software companies benefit from transforming global business. Colleges and education systems will focus on the most established software, encouraging companies to leverage this talent and buy more subscriptions.

basis_points.basis_title: Minimal external competition due to tailored products
basis_points.basis_description: Software companies deal with minimal external competition because of their highly tailored product. Developers are even implementing low-code solutions to enable client customization of software, further locking the user into a solution.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Massive software companies eat smaller players
concentration_points.concentration_description: The sheer sizes of SAP and Microsoft exert a gravitational pull on the entire industry and beyond. Companies with larger product portfolios, both software and non-software products, can cross-sell items.
Besides the product production power of the major players, each holds a library of patents, ensuring that no minor player dares copy their income-generating features.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Larger businesses have more well-known software
concentration_points.concentration_description: Larger businesses tend to have more well-known software, which increases the chance that employees will know how to use the software; this decreases the training cost for client companies.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Legal and licensing expenses are noteworthy in ensuring compliance with international data protection regulations and intellectual property rights.
Investing in customer success initiatives separates leading business analytics software providers from their competitors and can be a substantial miscellaneous cost.
Training programs ensuring employees remain up-to-date with latest technologies represent a continuous investment beyond initial recruitment.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Labor costs remain an omnipresent challenge
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Labor costs remain an omnipresent challenge—salient in tech hubs where talent competition inflates wages. Prudent software startups counter this by fostering enticing company cultures with career advancement opportunities, competitive compensation packages, and remote work possibilities.
On the technological frontier, automating routine tasks with AI can taper headcounts while contracting labor affords flexibility and scalability, easing financial pressures.
Additionally, creating easily integrated software amplifies appeal and can establish lucrative partnerships that subsidize growth.

volatility_points.volatility_title: COVID-19 failed to introduce negative volatile pressure
volatility_points.volatility_description: While COVID-19 dramatically damaged business confidence, many businesses had to shift to connect with new clients in changing markets.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Business Cycle Changes are Set to Affect Volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Software is a capital suitable for businesses, so income depends on corporate profit, business sentiment and the company's willingness to update its systems. Volatility due to business cycles is balanced out by long-term trends that favor the widespread adoption of technology.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Product Release Timing Can Create Artificial Volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Software providers in the U.S. often face revenue volatility around the timing of new product launches, which can lead to significant swings in financial performance.

FAQs.question: How has the shift towards conducting business online affected demand for your services?
FAQs.answer: The shift online has opened a new distribution channel for industry companies; the cloud. Through the cloud, customers can pay for services on a subscription basis and receive regular software updates. The percentage of business conducted online soared in 2020 amid the pandemic.

FAQs.question: Has technology (i.e. data storage and analytics) affected the type of customers you sell to?
FAQs.answer: Compared to costly one-time purchases, cloud-based solutions are marketable to a wider range of businesses, especially SMBs, as these subscription options enable customers to pay less upfront and develop stronger long-term relationships with developers.

FAQs.question: Is your company strategically located in a region that acts to your benefit? Have you re-considered your location and remote-work offerings as a result of the pandemic?
FAQs.answer: To attract the best talent, companies traditionally look to the Silicon Valley area of California, as well as Seattle, New York City, Austin and Boston as major tech hubs. The pandemic caused a large increase in remote work in this industry and may have led to less emphasis on location in traditional tech hubs.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to rising wages in recent years?
FAQs.answer: The industry as a whole has been exposed to rising wages over the past five years as demand for employees is extremely competitive. This industry encompasses some of the largest and cash-ready corporations, including Microsoft, IBM and Oracle, who all push wages up. Even in 2020, during the pandemic, industry wages increased.

FAQs.question: Has your company prepared adequately to address the increased security risks posed by digital data storage?
FAQs.answer: The cyberattacks on Equifax and web hosting companies a few years ago, which have temporarily shut down Twitter and Spotify, are among a number of high-profile cyberattacks in recent years. Developers of internet-hosted (cloud) software must ensure that customers' data, designs and technology are protected.

FAQs.question: Has your company been able to keep current with changing digital interfaces? How regularly do you update your interfaces?
FAQs.answer: It is vital for software developers, especially smaller companies, to be aware of changing consumer preferences. The shift to the cloud is extremely important in this industry, as more customers demand the flexibility and affordability that only the cloud offers. SaaS distribution models have made frequent updates more common.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: On a state and local level, there are a number of groups that are looking to promote software and technology jobs in their area.

FAQs.question: Have any recent regulatory changes significantly affected your operations?
FAQs.answer: Regulation plays a small role in the industry; given the highly fragmented nature of the industry, antitrust litigators generally do not scrutinize industry companies. The industry is anticipating increased federal scrutiny and potential regulation over the next four years under the new Biden administration.

FAQs.question: Do you have any big projects that require capital financing on the horizon? Did you benefit from lower interest rates in 2020?
FAQs.answer: Capital requirements are small in this industry. However, new entrants will be challenged to find and fund the right employees, often the bedrock of any successful company. Interest rates were cut sharply in 2020, to stimulate the economy during the pandemic. This may have made financing cheaper to secure.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare with your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Profit remains high in this industry, carried by large and high-market share companies like Oracle, SAP and IBM. Salesforce, which commands a sizable share of the market, has seen profit surge over the past five years.

FAQs.question: How intuitive are your programs and services? How can you better streamline your offerings for ease of use?
FAQs.answer: Ease-of-use is an important design element for enterprise software because it has such a large and diverse user base. The transition to SaaS distribution in recent years has made regular, user-friendly updates crucial to maintaining user satisfaction.

FAQs.question: How quickly do you integrate new technology into your offerings? How does your company keep up to date with the latest technology?
FAQs.answer: Software industries are subject to extremely quick technological advancement. Adopting new technologies faster than competitors provides distinct advantages.

FAQs.question: Research and Development
FAQs.answer: Research and development is one of the most substantial cost structure components in 2023. R&D expenditure dipped in 2020 during the pandemic.

FAQs.question: How do you make sure your prices are attractive to clients? How do you balance price rates to stimulate demand? Was price-based competition heightened by the pandemic?
FAQs.answer: Products are priced on value rather than cost. The most successful operators in this industry are adept at crafting price structures that reflect the potential value of an enterprise solution to a customer rather than the cost of producing that software. The pandemic reduced corporate profit and consumer spending, which may have made competitive pricing more important.

FAQs.question: How have high interest rates affected your company in the past? What percentage of your products and services are bought on credit?
FAQs.answer: The level and movement of interest rates have a powerful influence on spending and investment decisions. When interest rates are high, it is more expensive for companies to raise capital and invest in operations, which includes purchases of enterprise software. Interest rates were lowered during the pandemic in 2020, in an effort to increase economic activity.

FAQs.question: Do you encounter changes in demand as a result of fluctuating corporate profit levels? What kinds of businesses comprise your clientele?
FAQs.answer: Enterprise software is a capital expenditure for businesses that helps management make more informed decisions. Companies tend to invest in software when corporate profit is high. Conversely, when profit is low, companies reduce their spending on new software. Corporate profit fell in 2020, which may have reduced demand for certain industry software products.

FAQs.question: How has the increased normalization of industry technology affected your revenue? What advanced and value-added services do you offer clients?
FAQs.answer: Private investment in computers and software fell in 2020 during the pandemic. This may have reduced industry demand.
